com.bigdata.rdf.sparql.ast.eval.reif

Class TestReificationDoneRightEval

  • java.lang.Object
    • junit.framework.Assert
      • junit.framework.TestCase
        • junit.framework.TestCase2
          • com.bigdata.bop.engine.AbstractQueryEngineTestCase

                  • com.bigdata.rdf.sparql.ast.eval.reif.TestReificationDoneRightEval
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    junit.framework.Test

    public class TestReificationDoneRightEval
extends AbstractDataDrivenSPARQLTestCase
    Reification Done Right test suite.

    The basic extension is: 

     BIND(<> as ?sid)
    This triple reference pattern associates the bindings on the subject, predicate, and object positions of some triple pattern with the binding on a variable for the triple. Except in the case where ?sid is already bound, the triple pattern itself is processed normally and the bindings are concatenated to form a representation of a triple, which is then bound on ?sid. When ?sid is bound, it is decomposed into its subject, predicate, and object components and those values are bound on the triple pattern.

    When there are nested triple reference patterns, then they are just unwound into simple triple reference patterns. A variables is created to provide the association between each nested triple reference pattern and role played by that triple reference pattern in the outer triple reference pattern.

    We can handle this internally by allowing an optional named/positional role for a Predicate which (when defined) becomes bound to the composition of the (subject, predicate, and object) bindings for the predicate. It might be easiest to handle this if we allowed the [c] position to be optional as well and ignored it when in a triples only mode. The sid/triple binding would always be "in scope" but it would only be interpreted when non-null (either a constant or a variable).

    Author:
    Bryan Thompson
    See Also:
    Reification Done Right

        public void test_reificationDoneRight_01()
                                  throws Exception
        Simple query involving alice, bob, and an information extractor. For this version of the test the data are modeled in the source file using RDF reification. 
         select ?src where {
   ?x foaf:name "Alice" .
   ?y foaf:name "Bob" .
   <> dc:source ?src .
 }

        public void test_reificationDoneRight_03()
                                  throws Exception
         prefix : 
 SELECT ?a {
    BIND( <> AS ?ignored )
 }
 
         prefix :  .
 :a1  :b  :c .
 :a2  :b  :c .
 <<:a2 :b :c>>  :d  :e .
 <<:a3 :b :c>>  :d  :e .
 
         ?a
 ---
 :a1
 :a2
        Throws:

      • test_reificationDoneRight_03a

        public void test_reificationDoneRight_03a()
                                   throws Exception
         prefix : 
 SELECT ?a ?e {
    BIND( <> AS ?sid ) .
    ?sid :d ?e .
 }
 
         prefix :  .
 :a1  :b  :c .
 :a2  :b  :c .
 <<:a2 :b :c>>  :d  :e .
 <<:a3 :b :c>>  :d  :e .
 
         ?a  ?e
 ------
 :a2 :e

      • getProperties

        public Properties getProperties()
        Description copied from class: TestCase2
        Reads in the configuration properties for the test from a variety of resources and returns a properties hierarchy. If a property name is not bound at the top-level of the returned Properties object, then the lower levels of the hierarchy are recursively searched.

        The hierarchy is constructed from the following properties files in the following order. The first property file in this list corresponds to the top of the property hierarchy. The last property file in this list corresponds to the bottom of the property hierarchy. The property resources are:

        1. The System properties specified using the -D argument on the command line.
        2. ${user.home}/build.properties. ${user.home} is the value of the Java system environment variable named "user.home" and corresponds to the user home directory. A warning is logged if this properties file does not exist. Note: The JUnit UI can wind up with a different value for this property than when you execute tests without the UI. It is an error if the properties file exists but can not be read.
        3. {class}.properties, where {class} is the class name reported by Java reflection, is loaded iff it is found.
        4. {class} is repeatedly truncated by dropping the last package name component to generate a package name. If a properties file named "test.properties" exists in that package then those properties are loaded.
        Overrides:
        getProperties in class AbstractASTEvaluationTestCase
        Returns:
        A Properties object that supplies bindings for property names according to the described hierarchy among property resources. The returned Properties is NOT cached. TODO This does not handle the recursive truncation of the class name to search for "test.properties" yet.
